title: 107_hr5568
content: The "Seniors' Retirement Recovery Act of 2002" repeals the 1993 income tax increase on Social Security benefits. The "Seniors' Retirement Recovery Act of 2002" repeals the 1993 income tax increase on Social Security benefits. It amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to restore the prior law formula for including Social Security benefits in gross income for taxpayers. The base amount for calculating this inclusion is set at $25,000, $32,000 for joint returns, and zero for certain taxpayers. The text discusses changes in tax laws related to Social Security benefits, including adjustments to the base amount for including benefits in gross income. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, affecting taxpayers who are married but do not file joint returns and do not live apart from their spouse during the taxable year. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to percentages in certain sections of the code. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, affecting taxpayers who are married but do not file joint returns and do not live apart from their spouse during the taxable year. Effective dates for the amendments are specified for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 apply to benefits and tax liabilities after December 31, 2001. Appropriations to the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund are made to offset revenue reductions caused by the Act. Transfers will replicate what would have occurred without the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury or delegate must report annually to the House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committee on the transfers made under this subsection. SEC. 3. Age for beginning mandatory distributions increased to 80. The age for beginning mandatory distributions from qualified pension plans, individual retirement plans, and Roth IRAs is increased to 80, as per the amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The age for mandatory distributions from retirement plans is increased to 80, as per amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The changes apply to distributions after the enactment of the Act.
